facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2433 of 1968 filed by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2433 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated August 9, 1968 of the Labour Court Gauhati in Case No. 6 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated August 9, 1968 of the Labour Court Gauhati in Case No. 6 of 1968 published in the Assam Gazette dated the 4th September 1968.

facts.text: Award published in the Assam Gazette dated the 4th September 1968.

anchor.surface_text: published in the Assam Gazette dated the 4th September 1968. Sen, G. Mukhuty and D. N. Gupta, for the Appellant. L. Sen Gupta and S. K. Nandy, for the respondents.

facts.text: At the commencement of the year 1966, the appellant published a list of holidays stating Kali Puja holiday on Friday, 11th November 1966.

anchor.surface_text: According to the usual practice, at the companymencement of the year 1966, the appellant had published a list of holidays for that year. According to this list, the holiday for Kali Puja was stated to be on Friday, the 11th November, 1966.

facts.text: On November 5, 1966, the appellant notified that the factory will remain closed for Kali Puja on Friday, 11th November 1966.

anchor.surface_text: On November 5, 1966, the appellant numberified that the factory will remain closed for Kali Puja on Friday, the 11th November,1966. This numberification was only on the basis of the list of holidays referred to earlier.

facts.text: Workmen represented by two unions: Amco Employees Association and Amco Sramik Sangha, with Sangha representing the majority.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen in this companypany were represented by two unions  1  Amco Employees Association  hereinafter referred to as the Association  and  2  Amco Sramik Sangha  hereinafter referred to as the Sangh  . There is numbercontroversy that the Sangha represented the majority of the workmen of this companypany.

facts.text: On November 10, 1966, General Secretary of Sangha wrote letter to Factory Manager requesting closure on 12th November 1966 for Kali Puja instead of 11th.

anchor.surface_text: On November 10, 1966, the General Secretary of the Sangha wrote a letter to the factory Manager of the appellant requesting him to close the factory on Saturday, the 12th November, 1966, on account of Kali Puja instead of the 11th instant as already numberified by the company- pany on November 5, 1966.

facts.text: Sangha requested factory kept working on 11th November 1966 per timings mentioned.

anchor.surface_text: A further request was made in this letter that the factory may be kept working on Friday, the 11th November, in accordance with the timings mentioned therein.

facts.text: Sangha stated if request not accepted, large number of workmen will not attend on 12th November, resulting in heavy loss of production.

anchor.surface_text: The General Secretary further stated in this letter that if the request of change in the holiday is number accepted, a large number of workmen will number be attending on Saturday, the 12th November, which will result in heavy loss of production.

facts.text: On November 10, 1966, appellant put up notice acceding to Sangha request, factory closed 12th November, open 11th November.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of this letter, the appellant put up a numberice the same day that in response to the request of the Sangha, the factory will remain- closed for Kali Puja on Saturday, the 12th November, instead of Friday, the 11th, as previously numberified.

facts.text: Notice of November 10, 1966 cancelled previous notice of November 5, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: This numberice further stated that the factory will remain open on Friday, the 11th November during the hours mentioned therein. Quite naturally, this numberice cancelled the previous numberice dated November 5, 1966.

facts.text: On November 10, 1966, Association addressed letter to management that change of holiday not justified, 11th November should stand.

anchor.surface_text: After the companypanys numberice regarding the change of holiday for Diwali was put up on the numberice-board, the Association, on the same day  November 10, 1966 , addressed a letter to the management that the change of holiday for Diwali was number justified and that the date originally declared as a holiday, namely, the 11th November, should be allowed to stand.

facts.text: Company did not accede to Association request, most Association workmen did not attend work on November 11, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany obviously did number accede to this request of the Association with the result that most of the workmen attached to the association did number attend to work on November 11, 1966.

facts.text: Appellant did not pay wages for November 11, 1966 to absent workmen on ground they were absent from duty.

anchor.surface_text: The wages for that day were number paid by the appellant to those workmen on the ground that they were absent from duty.

facts.text: On December 30, 1967, 83 respondents filed application under section 33-A before Labour Court Gauhati.

anchor.surface_text: Nearly a year later on December 30, 1967, the respondents in this appeal, 83 in number, filed an application before the Labour Court, Gauhati, under section 33-A of the Act.

facts.text: Labour Court held alteration of holiday from 11th to 12th November amounted to change in condition of service, violated section 33 read with 9-A, granted relief to workmen.

anchor.surface_text: But the Labour Court held that, as the holiday has been originally fixed for the 11th November by the numberice dated November 5, 1966, on the basis of the list of holidays announced by the companypany, the alteration of the holiday from 11th to 12th November, though at the request of the majority of the workmen, amounted to a change in the companydition  if service and as such, the procedure under section 9-A should have been followed.

facts.text: Labour Court accepted Sangha represented majority of workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court has accepted the plea of the management that the Sangha represented the majority of the workmen of the appellant.

facts.text: Labour Court found appellant altered date from 11th to 12th at specific request of Sangha.

anchor.surface_text: It has further found that the appellant altered the date from 11th to 12th at the specific request of the Sangha.

facts.text: List of holidays published at beginning of 1966 stated subject to modification if thought necessary.

anchor.surface_text: In the numberice published at the beginning of the year 1966 regarding the holidays for the said year, the appellant has numberdoubt stated that Friday, the 11th November, will be a holiday for Kali Puja. But there is a statement in this numberice to the effect that this list is subject to modification, if thought necessary.

facts.text: Under paragraph 6 of company's certified Standing Orders, notice specifying holidays shall be posted.

anchor.surface_text: Under paragraph 6 of the companypanys certified Sanding Orders, it is provided that Notice specifying  a  the days observed by the Factory as holidays and  b  pay days, shall be posted as required by the Factory Act and the payment of wages Act respectively.

facts.text: Evidence shows workmen actually celebrated Diwali on 12th November 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence on the side of the respondents shows that the workmen actually celebrated Diwali ,on the 12th November, which was declared to be a holiday.

facts.text: Management pleaded previous instances when holiday once fixed altered at request of workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The management also cited certain previous instances when the holiday for Holiday or for Diwali once fixed had been altered at the request of the workmen.

facts.text: Respondents claimed one day holiday for Kali Puja allowed for number of years, become condition of service.

anchor.surface_text: According to them, one day holiday for Kali Puja was being allowed for a number of years and that it has become a companydition of service.

facts.text: Supreme Court held alteration of date of holiday for Diwali not a change in conditions of service.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the alteration of the date regarding the holiday for Diwali, from 1 1 the to the next day, cannot be companysidered to be an alteration in the companyditions of service.

issues.text: whether there has been any change effected in the conditions of service of the workmen by altering the holiday of Diwali from November 11 to the next day

anchor.surface_text: The management contested the application on the ground that there has been no change effected in the conditions of service of the workmen by altering the holiday of Diwali from November 11, to the next day. As the holiday is for Diwali and as the majority of the workmen specifically desired the holiday on the 12th November the change was made to suit the convenience of the workmen.

arguments.claim: No question of cancellation of holiday; workmen had holiday on 12th

anchor.surface_text: Mr. B. Sen, on behalf of the appellant company supported the stand taken by it before the Labour Court He urged that there is no question of any cancellation of a holiday that the workmen were entitled to, in which case it may be stated that the condition of service is effected.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: appellant. In particular, Mr. Sen Gupta pointed out hat if the employer wanted to effect a change in the date of the holiday, it should have been don

arguments.claim: Previous occasions such changes effected at workmen request

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the workmen did have a holiday for Diwali on the 12th November. The counsel also referred us to the evidence on record to show that on previous occasions such changes had been effected in the holidays when a request was made by the workmen concerned.

arguments.claim: Change in condition of service effected; adopt Labour Court reasons

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen Gupta, learned counsel for the respondents, has adopted the reasons given by the Labour Court for holding that a change in the condition of service has been effected by the appellant.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: appellant. In particular, Mr. Sen Gupta pointed out hat if the employer wanted to effect a change in the date of the holiday, it should have been don

arguments.claim: To change date, should enter settlement with workmen per proviso (a) to s9-A

anchor.surface_text: In particular, Mr. Sen Gupta pointed out that if the employer wanted to effect a change in the date of the holiday, it should have been done by the appellant entering into a settlement with the work- men, as contemplated by clause (a) of the proviso to section 9-A.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: iwali. In fact they have got it on the 12th November, 1966. In The Workmen of M S. Sur Iron Steel Co. Pvt. Ltd. v. M S. Sur Iron Steel Co. Pvt. Ltd.,

arguments.claim: No power to change even if majority desired

anchor.surface_text: The sum and substance of the arguments of Mr. Sen Gupta was that the appellant, having fixed the holiday for Diwali as per its previous circular, had no power to change the same even though a majority of the workmen had desired the appellant to do so.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: J 570.  2  1972 11 LLJ. 259. the facts of that case it is seen that Sunday had been a holiday in the factory companycerned for a long number of years.

arguments.claim: Alteration of date of holiday not change in conditions of service

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the alteration of the date regarding the holiday for Diwali, from 11th to the next day, cannot be considered to be an alteration in the conditions of service.

arguments.claim: Workmen entitled to holiday for Diwali, but date decided by management in consultation with workmen

anchor.surface_text: The workmen may be entitled to have a holiday for Diwali. But on what particular day Diwali falls or it is being observed and a holiday is to be declared, is a matter to be decided by the management in consultation with the workmen.

arguments.claim: Changing date at majority request not alteration in conditions; no deprivation

anchor.surface_text: If a large body of the workmen require a change in the date of the holiday on the ground that the festival is not being observed on the day originally fixed and the management changes the date, it cannot be stated that there is an alteration in the conditions of service.

arguments.claim: List of holidays subject to modification if thought necessary

anchor.surface_text: In the notice published at the beginning of the year 1966 regarding the holidays for the said year, the appellant has no doubt stated that Friday, the 11th November, will be a holiday for Kali Puja. But there is a statement in this notice to the effect that this list is subject to modification, if thought necessary.

arguments.claim: Notices comply with Standing Orders para 6

anchor.surface_text: Under paragraph 6 of the companys certified Standing Orders, it is provided that Notice specifying (a) the days observed by the Factory as holidays and (b) pay days, shall be posted as required by the Factory Act and the payment of wages Act respectively.

arguments.claim: Distinction from Sur Iron Steel: no specific entry for weekly off; govt notification

anchor.surface_text: In The Workmen of M/s. Sur Iron Steel Co. Pvt. Ltd. v. M/s. Sur Iron Steel Co. Pvt. Ltd., and another, the workmen contended that the change in the weekly off-day, from Sunday to Saturday, without complying with the provisions of section 9-A, was illegal.

arguments.claim: Distinction from Tata Iron: there Sunday cancelled and mid-week given; long custom

anchor.surface_text: The decision in M/s Tata Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. vs. The Workmen and others does not advance the case of the respondents. From the facts of that case it is seen that Sunday had been a holiday in the factory concerned for a long number of years.

arguments.claim: Even if alteration amounts to change, no contravention of s9A as majority requested

anchor.surface_text: Even assuming that the alteration of the date of the holiday for Diwali will amount to a condition of service, there is no question, in this case, of a contravention of section 9-A, when the majority of the workmen themselves requested the employer to make the alteration.

arguments.claim: Employer within rights under s33(2)(a)

anchor.surface_text: The employer was within its rights under section 33 (2) (a).

arguments.claim: Workmen actually celebrated Diwali on 12th

anchor.surface_text: The evidence on the side of the respondents shows that the workmen actually celebrated Diwali on the 12th November, which was declared to be a holiday.

holdings.text: the alteration of the date regarding the holiday for Diwali, from 11th to the next day, cannot be considered to be an alteration in the conditions of service

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the alteration of the date regarding the holiday for Diwali, from 1 1 the to the next day, cannot be companysidered to be an alteration in the companyditions of service. The workmen may be entitled to have a holiday for Diwali. But on what particular day Diwali Calls or it is being observed and a holiday is to be declared, is a matter to be decided by the management in companysultation with the workmen.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Workmen entitled to Diwali holiday but specific date determined by management in consultation with workmen based on observance; no deprivation of holiday itself as provided on day majority celebrated

holdings.text: no question of a contravention of section 9-A, when the majority of the workmen themselves requested the employer to make the alteration

anchor.surface_text: Even assuming that the alteration of the date of the holiday for Diwali will amount to a condition of service, there is no question, in this case, of a contravention of section 9-A, when the majority of the workmen themselves requested the employer to make the alteration. The employer was within its rights under section 3 3  2   a .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even if assumed to be change in conditions, majority request means no need for s9A procedure as object of s9A is to allow workmen to consider and represent on proposed changes

holdings.text: The employer was within its rights under section 33 (2) (a)

anchor.surface_text: The employer was within its rights under section 33 (2) (a). The evidence on the side of the respondents shows that the workmen actually celebrated Diwali ,on the 12th November, which was declared to be a holiday.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standing orders permit posting notices for holidays which were complied with; change permitted during pendency under s33(2)(a)

holdings.text: the notice dated November 10, 1966, by the management regarding the 12th November being a holiday for Diwali, acceding to the request of the workmen, must also be considered to satisfy the provisions of this clause in the Standing Orders

anchor.surface_text: Under paragraph 6 of the companypanys certified Sanding Orders, it is provided that Notice specifying  a  the days observed by the Factory as holidays and  b  pay days, shall be posted as required by the Factory Act and the payment of wages Act respectively. There is numbercontroversy that the list of holidays published at the beginning of the year 1966 as well as the circular dated November 5, 1966 are in companyformity with this provision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notices posted as required by para 6 of certified standing orders for holidays

holdings.text: this decision did not express any opinion on the question whether the alteration of the weekly off-day from Sunday to Saturday, amounts to a change in the conditions of service

anchor.surface_text: In The Workmen of M/s. Sur Iron Steel Co. Pvt. Ltd. v. M/s. Sur Iron Steel Co. Pvt. Ltd., and another 1 , the workmen companytended that the change in the weekly off-day, from Sunday to Saturday, without companyplying with the provisions of section 9-A, was illegal. This Court rejected that companytention on two grounds that  1  there was numberspecific entry in the Fourth Schedule companyering a companydition of service relating to a weekly off-day and  2  even assuming that the grant of a weekly off-day falls under item 4 of the Fourth Schedule,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sur Iron Steel distinguished on grounds of no specific schedule entry and govt exemption notification under s9B

holdings.text: canceling the holiday enjoyed on Sunday amounts, in the circumstances, to a change in the conditions of service

anchor.surface_text: The decision in M s Tata Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. vs. The Workmen and others 2  does number advance the case of the respondents. From  1  1971  1  LLJ 570.  2  1972 11 LLJ. 259. the facts of that case it is seen that Sunday had been a holiday in the factory companycerned for a long number of years. The companypany, for the reasons stated in the judgment, cancelled this holiday and in turn gave a holiday in the mid-week without following the procedure under section 9-A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tata Iron distinguished as involved long custom Sunday holiday cancelled for mid-week without procedure, unlike flexible festival date here

precedents.citation: The Workmen of M S. Sur Iron Steel Co. Pvt. Ltd. v. M S. Sur Iron Steel Co. Pvt. Ltd., and another 1

anchor.surface_text: The Workmen of M S. Sur Iron Steel Co. Pvt. Ltd. v. M S. Sur Iron Steel Co. Pvt. Ltd., and another 1 , the workmen companytended that the change in the weekly off-day, from Sunday to Saturday, without companyplying with the provisions of section 9-A, was illegal.

precedents.case_name: Workmen of M/s Sur Iron Steel Co Pvt Ltd v M/s Sur Iron Steel Co Pvt Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: change in weekly off-day from Sunday to Saturday does not attract section 9-A as no specific entry in Fourth Schedule and exempted by notification under section 9-B
precedents.cited_holding: rejected contention that change in weekly off-day without section 9-A compliance is illegal

precedents.citation: M s Tata Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. vs. The Workmen and others 2

anchor.surface_text: M s Tata Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. vs. The Workmen and others 2  does number advance the case of the respondents. From  1  1971  1  LLJ 570.  2  1972 11 LLJ. 259. the facts of that case it is seen that Sunday had been a holiday

precedents.case_name: M/s Tata Iron and Steel Co Ltd v The Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: cancelling long-standing Sunday holiday and providing mid-week holiday amounts to change in conditions of service requiring section 9-A compliance
precedents.cited_holding: alteration of Sunday holiday to mid-week in particular circumstances is change in conditions of service

precedents.citation: M s. Tata Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. The workmen and others 1

anchor.surface_text: M s. Tata Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. The workmen and others 1  that the real object and purpose of section 9-A is to afford an opportunity to the workmen to companysider the effect of a proposed change and. if necessary, to represent their view on the proposal.

precedents.case_name: M/s Tata Iron and Steel Co Ltd v The Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: object of section 9-A is to give workmen opportunity to consider proposed change and represent views
precedents.cited_holding: real object and purpose of section 9-A is to afford opportunity to workmen to consider effect of proposed change

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the alteration of the date regarding the holiday for Diwali, from 1 1 the to the next day, cannot be companysidered to be an alteration in the companyditions of service. The workmen may be entitled to have a holiday for Diwali. But on what particular day Diwali Calls or it is being observed and a holiday is to be declared, is a matter to be decided by the management in companysultation with the workmen. If a large body I of the workmen require a change in the date of the holiday on the ground that the festival is number being observed on the day originally fixed and the management changes the date,, it cannot be stated that there is an alteration in the companyditions of service.

outcome.relief_summary: No change in conditions of service by altering holiday date at majority workmen request; no contravention of section 9-A or section 33; Labour Court finding reversed

anchor.surface_text: Even assuming that the alteration of the date of the holiday for Diwali will amount to a condition of service, there is no question, in this case, of a contravention of section 9-A, when the majority of the workmen themselves requested the employer to make the alteration. The employer was within its rights under section 3 3  2   a .

anchor.surface_text: The employer was within its rights under section 33 (2) (a). The evidence on the side of the respondents shows that the workmen actually celebrated Diwali ,on the 12th November, which was declared to be a holiday.

In our opinion, the alteration of the date regarding the holiday for Diwali, from 1 1 the to the next day, cannot be companysidered to be an alteration in the companyditions of service. The workmen may be entitled to have a holiday for Diwali. But on what particular day Diwali Calls or it is being observed and a holiday is to be declared, is a matter to be decided by the management in companysultation with the workmen. If a large body I of the workmen require a change in the date of the holiday on the ground that the festival is number being observed on the day originally fixed and the management changes the date,, it cannot be stated that there is an alteration in the companyditions of service.

In our opinion, the alteration of the date regarding the holiday for Diwali, from 1 1 the to the next day, cannot be companysidered to be an alteration in the companyditions of service. The workmen may be entitled to have a holiday for Diwali. But on what particular day Diwali Calls or it is being observed and a holiday is to be declared, is a matter to be decided by the management in companysultation with the workmen. If a large body I of the workmen require a change in the date of the holiday on the ground that the festival is number being observed on the day originally fixed and the management changes the date,, it cannot be stated that there is an alteration in the companyditions of service.
